017package imagingbook.parboiled.parser;
018
019import imagingbook.parboiled.Action;
020import imagingbook.parboiled.Rule;
021import imagingbook.parboiled.annotations.Cached;
022import imagingbook.parboiled.annotations.DontExtend;
023import imagingbook.parboiled.annotations.DontLabel;
024import imagingbook.parboiled.annotations.SkipActionsInPredicates;
025import imagingbook.parboiled.annotations.SuppressNode;
026import imagingbook.parboiled.annotations.SuppressSubnodes;
027import imagingbook.parboiled.common.Utils;
028import imagingbook.parboiled.errors.GrammarException;
029import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.ActionMatcher;
030import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.AnyMatcher;
031import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.AnyOfMatcher;
032import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.CharIgnoreCaseMatcher;
033import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.CharMatcher;
034import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.CharRangeMatcher;
035import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.EmptyMatcher;
036import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.FirstOfMatcher;
037import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.FirstOfStringsMatcher;
038import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.NothingMatcher;
039import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.OneOrMoreMatcher;
040import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.OptionalMatcher;
041import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.SequenceMatcher;
042import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.StringMatcher;
043import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.TestMatcher;
044import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.TestNotMatcher;
045import imagingbook.parboiled.matchers.ZeroOrMoreMatcher;
046import imagingbook.parboiled.support.Characters;
047import imagingbook.parboiled.support.Chars;
048import imagingbook.parboiled.support.Checks;
049
050import java.util.Arrays;
051
052import static imagingbook.parboiled.common.Preconditions.checkArgNotNull;
053import static imagingbook.parboiled.common.Preconditions.checkArgument;
054
055/**
056 * Base class of all parboiled parsers. Defines the basic rule creation methods.
057 *
058 * @param <V> the type of the parser values
059 */
060@SuppressWarnings( {"UnusedDeclaration"})
061public abstract class BaseParser<V> extends BaseActions<V> {
062
063    /**
064     * Matches the {@link Chars#EOI} (end of input) character.
065     */
066    public static final Rule EOI = new CharMatcher(Chars.EOI);
067
068    /**
069     * Matches the special {@link Chars#INDENT} character produces by the org.parboiled.buffers.IndentDedentInputBuffer
070     */
071    public static final Rule INDENT = new CharMatcher(Chars.INDENT);
072
073    /**
074     * Matches the special {@link Chars#DEDENT} character produces by the org.parboiled.buffers.IndentDedentInputBuffer
075     */
076    public static final Rule DEDENT = new CharMatcher(Chars.DEDENT);
077
078    /**
079     * Matches any character except {@link Chars#EOI}.
080     */
081    public static final Rule ANY = new AnyMatcher();
082
083    /**
084     * Matches nothing and always succeeds.
085     */
086    public static final Rule EMPTY = new EmptyMatcher();
087
088    /**
089     * Matches nothing and always fails.
090     */
091    public static final Rule NOTHING = new NothingMatcher();
092
093    /**
094     * Creates a new instance of this parsers class using the no-arg constructor. If no no-arg constructor
095     * exists this method will fail with a java.lang.NoSuchMethodError.
096     * Using this method is faster than using {@link Parboiled#createParser(Class, Object...)} for creating
097     * new parser instances since this method does not use reflection.
098     *
099     * @param <P> the parser class
100     * @return a new parser instance
101     */
102    public <P extends BaseParser<V>> P newInstance() {
103        throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
104                "Illegal parser instance, you have to use Parboiled.createParser(...) to create your parser instance!");
105    }
106
107    /**
108     * Explicitly creates a rule matching the given character. Normally you can just specify the character literal
109     * directly in you rule description. However, if you don't want to go through {@link #fromCharLiteral(char)},
110     * e.g. because you redefined it, you can also use this wrapper.
111     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
112     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
113     *
114     * @param c the char to match
115     * @return a new rule
116     */
117    @Cached
118    @DontLabel
119    public Rule Ch(char c) {
120        return new CharMatcher(c);
121    }
122
123    /**
124     * Explicitly creates a rule matching the given character case-independently.
125     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
126     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
127     *
128     * @param c the char to match independently of its case
129     * @return a new rule
130     */
131    @Cached
132    @DontLabel
133    public Rule IgnoreCase(char c) {
134        if (Character.isLowerCase(c) == Character.isUpperCase(c)) {
135            return Ch(c);
136        }
137        return new CharIgnoreCaseMatcher(c);
138    }
139
140    /**
141     * Creates a rule matching a range of characters from cLow to cHigh (both inclusively).
142     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
143     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
144     *
145     * @param cLow  the start char of the range (inclusively)
146     * @param cHigh the end char of the range (inclusively)
147     * @return a new rule
148     */
149    @Cached
150    @DontLabel
151    public Rule CharRange(char cLow, char cHigh) {
152        return cLow == cHigh ? Ch(cLow) : new CharRangeMatcher(cLow, cHigh);
153    }
154
155    /**
156     * Creates a new rule that matches any of the characters in the given string.
157     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
158     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
159     *
160     * @param characters the characters
161     * @return a new rule
162     */
163    @DontLabel
164    public Rule AnyOf(String characters) {
165        checkArgNotNull(characters, "characters");
166        return AnyOf(characters.toCharArray());
167    }
168
169    /**
170     * Creates a new rule that matches any of the characters in the given char array.
171     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
172     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
173     *
174     * @param characters the characters
175     * @return a new rule
176     */
177    @DontLabel
178    public Rule AnyOf(char[] characters) {
179        checkArgNotNull(characters, "characters");
180        checkArgument(characters.length > 0);
181        return characters.length == 1 ? Ch(characters[0]) : AnyOf(Characters.of(characters));
182    }
183
184    /**
185     * Creates a new rule that matches any of the given characters.
186     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
187     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
188     *
189     * @param characters the characters
190     * @return a new rule
191     */
192    @Cached
193    @DontLabel
194    public Rule AnyOf(Characters characters) {
195        checkArgNotNull(characters, "characters");
196        if (!characters.isSubtractive() && characters.getChars().length == 1) {
197            return Ch(characters.getChars()[0]);
198        }
199        if (characters.equals(Characters.NONE)) return NOTHING;
200        return new AnyOfMatcher(characters);
201    }
202
203    /**
204     * Creates a new rule that matches all characters except the ones in the given string and EOI.
205     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
206     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
207     *
208     * @param characters the characters
209     * @return a new rule
210     */
211    @DontLabel
212    public Rule NoneOf(String characters) {
213        checkArgNotNull(characters, "characters");
214        return NoneOf(characters.toCharArray());
215    }
216
217    /**
218     * Creates a new rule that matches all characters except the ones in the given char array and EOI.
219     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
220     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
221     *
222     * @param characters the characters
223     * @return a new rule
224     */
225    @DontLabel
226    public Rule NoneOf(char[] characters) {
227        checkArgNotNull(characters, "characters");
228        checkArgument(characters.length > 0);
229
230        // make sure to always exclude EOI as well
231        boolean containsEOI = false;
232        for (char c : characters) if (c == Chars.EOI) { containsEOI = true; break; }
233        if (!containsEOI) {
234            char[] withEOI = new char[characters.length + 1];
235            System.arraycopy(characters, 0, withEOI, 0, characters.length);
236            withEOI[characters.length] = Chars.EOI;
237            characters = withEOI;
238        }
239
240        return AnyOf(Characters.allBut(characters));
241    }
242
243    /**
244     * Explicitly creates a rule matching the given string. Normally you can just specify the string literal
245     * directly in you rule description. However, if you want to not go through {@link #fromStringLiteral(String)},
246     * e.g. because you redefined it, you can also use this wrapper.
247     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
248     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
249     *
250     * @param string the String to match
251     * @return a new rule
252     */
253    @DontLabel
254    public Rule String(String string) {
255        checkArgNotNull(string, "string");
256        return String(string.toCharArray());
257    }
258
259    /**
260     * Explicitly creates a rule matching the given string. Normally you can just specify the string literal
261     * directly in you rule description. However, if you want to not go through {@link #fromStringLiteral(String)},
262     * e.g. because you redefined it, you can also use this wrapper.
263     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
264     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
265     *
266     * @param characters the characters of the string to match
267     * @return a new rule
268     */
269    @Cached
270    @SuppressSubnodes
271    @DontLabel
272    public Rule String(char... characters) {
273        if (characters.length == 1) return Ch(characters[0]); // optimize one-char strings
274        Rule[] matchers = new Rule[characters.length];
275        for (int i = 0; i < characters.length; i++) {
276            matchers[i] = Ch(characters[i]);
277        }
278        return new StringMatcher(matchers, characters);
279    }
280
281    /**
282     * Explicitly creates a rule matching the given string in a case-independent fashion.
283     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
284     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
285     *
286     * @param string the string to match
287     * @return a new rule
288     */
289    @DontLabel
290    public Rule IgnoreCase(String string) {
291        checkArgNotNull(string, "string");
292        return IgnoreCase(string.toCharArray());
293    }
294
295    /**
296     * Explicitly creates a rule matching the given string in a case-independent fashion.
297     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
298     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
299     *
300     * @param characters the characters of the string to match
301     * @return a new rule
302     */
303    @Cached
304    @SuppressSubnodes
305    @DontLabel
306    public Rule IgnoreCase(char... characters) {
307        if (characters.length == 1) return IgnoreCase(characters[0]); // optimize one-char strings
308        Rule[] matchers = new Rule[characters.length];
309        for (int i = 0; i < characters.length; i++) {
310            matchers[i] = IgnoreCase(characters[i]);
311        }
312        return ((SequenceMatcher) Sequence(matchers)).label('"' + String.valueOf(characters) + '"');
313    }
314
315    /**
316     * Creates a new rule that successively tries all of the given subrules and succeeds when the first one of
317     * its subrules matches. If all subrules fail this rule fails as well.
318     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
319     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
320     *
321     * @param rule      the first subrule
322     * @param rule2     the second subrule
323     * @param moreRules the other subrules
324     * @return a new rule
325     */
326    @DontLabel
327    public Rule FirstOf(Object rule, Object rule2, Object... moreRules) {
328        checkArgNotNull(moreRules, "moreRules");
329        return FirstOf(Utils.arrayOf(rule, rule2, moreRules));
330    }
331
332    /**
333     * Creates a new rule that successively tries all of the given subrules and succeeds when the first one of
334     * its subrules matches. If all subrules fail this rule fails as well.
335     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
336     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
337     *
338     * @param rules the subrules
339     * @return a new rule
340     */
341    @Cached
342    @DontLabel
343    public Rule FirstOf(Object[] rules) {
344        checkArgNotNull(rules, "rules");
345        if (rules.length == 1) {
346            return toRule(rules[0]);
347        }
348        Rule[] convertedRules = toRules(rules);
349        char[][] chars = new char[rules.length][];
350        for (int i = 0, convertedRulesLength = convertedRules.length; i < convertedRulesLength; i++) {
351            Object rule = convertedRules[i];
352            if (rule instanceof StringMatcher) {
353                chars[i] = ((StringMatcher) rule).characters;
354            } else {
355                return new FirstOfMatcher(convertedRules);
356            }
357        }
358        return new FirstOfStringsMatcher(convertedRules, chars);
359    }
360
361    /**
362     * Creates a new rule that tries repeated matches of its subrule and succeeds if the subrule matches at least once.
363     * If the subrule does not match at least once this rule fails.
364     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
365     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
366     *
367     * @param rule the subrule
368     * @return a new rule
369     */
370    @Cached
371    @DontLabel
372    public Rule OneOrMore(Object rule) {
373        return new OneOrMoreMatcher(toRule(rule));
374    }
375
376    /**
377     * Creates a new rule that tries repeated matches of a sequence of the given subrules and succeeds if the sequence
378     * matches at least once. If the sequence does not match at least once this rule fails.
379     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
380     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
381     *
382     * @param rule      the first subrule
383     * @param rule2     the second subrule
384     * @param moreRules the other subrules
385     * @return a new rule
386     */
387    @DontLabel
388    public Rule OneOrMore(Object rule, Object rule2, Object... moreRules) {
389        checkArgNotNull(moreRules, "moreRules");
390        return OneOrMore(Sequence(rule, rule2, moreRules));
391    }
392
393    /**
394     * Creates a new rule that tries a match on its subrule and always succeeds, independently of the matching
395     * success of its sub rule.
396     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
397     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
398     *
399     * @param rule the subrule
400     * @return a new rule
401     */
402    @Cached
403    @DontLabel
404    public Rule Optional(Object rule) {
405        return new OptionalMatcher(toRule(rule));
406    }
407
408    /**
409     * Creates a new rule that tries a match on the sequence of the given subrules and always succeeds, independently
410     * of the matching success of its sub sequence.
411     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
412     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
413     *
414     * @param rule      the first subrule
415     * @param rule2     the second subrule
416     * @param moreRules the other subrules
417     * @return a new rule
418     */
419    @DontLabel
420    public Rule Optional(Object rule, Object rule2, Object... moreRules) {
421        checkArgNotNull(moreRules, "moreRules");
422        return Optional(Sequence(rule, rule2, moreRules));
423    }
424
425    /**
426     * Creates a new rule that only succeeds if all of its subrule succeed, one after the other.
427     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
428     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
429     *
430     * @param rule      the first subrule
431     * @param rule2     the second subrule
432     * @param moreRules the other subrules
433     * @return a new rule
434     */
435    @DontLabel
436    public Rule Sequence(Object rule, Object rule2, Object... moreRules) {
437        checkArgNotNull(moreRules, "moreRules");
438        return Sequence(Utils.arrayOf(rule, rule2, moreRules));
439    }
440
441    /**
442     * Creates a new rule that only succeeds if all of its subrule succeed, one after the other.
443     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
444     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
445     *
446     * @param rules the sub rules
447     * @return a new rule
448     */
449    @Cached
450    @DontLabel
451    public Rule Sequence(Object[] rules) {
452        checkArgNotNull(rules, "rules");
453        return rules.length == 1 ? toRule(rules[0]) : new SequenceMatcher(toRules(rules));
454    }
455
456    /**
457     * <p>Creates a new rule that acts as a syntactic predicate, i.e. tests the given sub rule against the current
458     * input position without actually matching any characters. Succeeds if the sub rule succeeds and fails if the
459     * sub rule rails. Since this rule does not actually consume any input it will never create a parse tree node.</p>
460     * <p>Also it carries a {@link SuppressNode} annotation, which means all sub nodes will also never create a parse
461     * tree node. This can be important for actions contained in sub rules of this rule that otherwise expect the
462     * presence of certain parse tree structures in their context.
463     * Also see {@link SkipActionsInPredicates}</p>
464     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
465     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
466     *
467     * @param rule the subrule
468     * @return a new rule
469     */
470    @Cached
471    @SuppressNode
472    @DontLabel
473    public Rule Test(Object rule) {
474        Rule subMatcher = toRule(rule);
475        return new TestMatcher(subMatcher);
476    }
477
478    /**
479     * <p>Creates a new rule that acts as a syntactic predicate, i.e. tests the sequence of the given sub rule against
480     * the current input position without actually matching any characters. Succeeds if the sub sequence succeeds and
481     * fails if the sub sequence rails. Since this rule does not actually consume any input it will never create a
482     * parse tree node.</p>
483     * <p>Also it carries a {@link SuppressNode} annotation, which means all sub nodes will also never create a parse
484     * tree node. This can be important for actions contained in sub rules of this rule that otherwise expect the
485     * presence of certain parse tree structures in their context.
486     * Also see {@link SkipActionsInPredicates}</p>
487     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
488     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
489     *
490     * @param rule      the first subrule
491     * @param rule2     the second subrule
492     * @param moreRules the other subrules
493     * @return a new rule
494     */
495    @DontLabel
496    public Rule Test(Object rule, Object rule2, Object... moreRules) {
497        checkArgNotNull(moreRules, "moreRules");
498        return Test(Sequence(rule, rule2, moreRules));
499    }
500
501    /**
502     * <p>Creates a new rule that acts as an inverse syntactic predicate, i.e. tests the given sub rule against the
503     * current input position without actually matching any characters. Succeeds if the sub rule fails and fails if the
504     * sub rule succeeds. Since this rule does not actually consume any input it will never create a parse tree node.</p>
505     * <p>Also it carries a {@link SuppressNode} annotation, which means all sub nodes will also never create a parse
506     * tree node. This can be important for actions contained in sub rules of this rule that otherwise expect the
507     * presence of certain parse tree structures in their context.
508     * Also see {@link SkipActionsInPredicates}</p>
509     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
510     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
511     *
512     * @param rule the subrule
513     * @return a new rule
514     */
515    @Cached
516    @SuppressNode
517    @DontLabel
518    public Rule TestNot(Object rule) {
519        Rule subMatcher = toRule(rule);
520        return new TestNotMatcher(subMatcher);
521    }
522
523    /**
524     * <p>Creates a new rule that acts as an inverse syntactic predicate, i.e. tests the sequence of the given sub rules
525     * against the current input position without actually matching any characters. Succeeds if the sub sequence fails
526     * and fails if the sub sequence succeeds. Since this rule does not actually consume any input it will never create
527     * a parse tree node.</p>
528     * <p>Also it carries a {@link SuppressNode} annotation, which means all sub nodes will also never create a parse
529     * tree node. This can be important for actions contained in sub rules of this rule that otherwise expect the
530     * presence of certain parse tree structures in their context.
531     * Also see {@link SkipActionsInPredicates}</p>
532     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
533     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
534     *
535     * @param rule      the first subrule
536     * @param rule2     the second subrule
537     * @param moreRules the other subrules
538     * @return a new rule
539     */
540    @DontLabel
541    public Rule TestNot(Object rule, Object rule2, Object... moreRules) {
542        checkArgNotNull(moreRules, "moreRules");
543        return TestNot(Sequence(rule, rule2, moreRules));
544    }
545
546    /**
547     * Creates a new rule that tries repeated matches of its subrule.
548     * Succeeds always, even if the subrule doesn't match even once.
549     * <p>Note: This methods carries a {@link Cached} annotation, which means that multiple invocations with the same
550     * argument will yield the same rule instance.</p>
551     *
552     * @param rule the subrule
553     * @return a new rule
554     */
555    @Cached
556    @DontLabel
557    public Rule ZeroOrMore(Object rule) {
558        return new ZeroOrMoreMatcher(toRule(rule));
559    }
560
561    /**
562     * Creates a new rule that tries repeated matches of the sequence of the given sub rules.
563     * Succeeds always, even if the sub sequence doesn't match even once.
564     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
565     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
566     *
567     * @param rule      the first subrule
568     * @param rule2     the second subrule
569     * @param moreRules the other subrules
570     * @return a new rule
571     */
572    @DontLabel
573    public Rule ZeroOrMore(Object rule, Object rule2, Object... moreRules) {
574        checkArgNotNull(moreRules, "moreRules");
575        return ZeroOrMore(Sequence(rule, rule2, moreRules));
576    }
577
578    /**
579     * Creates a new rule that repeatedly matches a given sub rule a certain fixed number of times.
580     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
581     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
582     *
583     * @param repetitions The number of repetitions to match. Must be >= 0.
584     * @param rule      the sub rule to match repeatedly.
585     * @return a new rule
586     */
587    @Cached
588    @DontLabel
589    public Rule NTimes(int repetitions, Object rule) {
590        return NTimes(repetitions, rule, null);
591    }
592
593    /**
594     * Creates a new rule that repeatedly matches a given sub rule a certain fixed number of times, optionally
595     * separated by a given separator rule.
596     * <p>Note: This methods provides caching, which means that multiple invocations with the same
597     * arguments will yield the same rule instance.</p>
598     *
599     * @param repetitions The number of repetitions to match. Must be >= 0.
600     * @param rule      the sub rule to match repeatedly.
601     * @param separator the separator to match, if null the individual sub rules will be matched without separator.
602     * @return a new rule
603     */
604    @Cached
605    @DontLabel
606    public Rule NTimes(int repetitions, Object rule, Object separator) {
607        checkArgNotNull(rule, "rule");
608        checkArgument(repetitions >= 0, "repetitions must be non-negative");
609        switch (repetitions) {
610            case 0: return EMPTY;
611            case 1: return toRule(rule);
612            default:
613                Object[] rules = new Object[separator == null ? repetitions : repetitions * 2 - 1];
614                if (separator != null) {
615                    for (int i = 0; i < rules.length; i++)
616                        rules[i] = i % 2 == 0 ? rule : separator;
617                } else Arrays.fill(rules, rule);
618                return Sequence(rules);
619        }
620    }
621
622    ///************************* "MAGIC" METHODS ***************************///
623
624    /**
625     * Explicitly marks the wrapped expression as an action expression.
626     * parboiled transforms the wrapped expression into an {@link Action} instance during parser construction.
627     *
628     * @param expression the expression to turn into an Action
629     * @return the Action wrapping the given expression
630     */
631    public static Action ACTION(boolean expression) {
632        throw new UnsupportedOperationException("ACTION(...) calls can only be used in Rule creating parser methods");
633    }
634
635    ///************************* HELPER METHODS ***************************///
636
637    /**
638     * Used internally to convert the given character literal to a parser rule.
639     * You can override this method, e.g. for specifying a Sequence that automatically matches all trailing
640     * whitespace after the character.
641     *
642     * @param c the character
643     * @return the rule
644     */
645    @DontExtend
646    protected Rule fromCharLiteral(char c) {
647        return Ch(c);
648    }
649
650    /**
651     * Used internally to convert the given string literal to a parser rule.
652     * You can override this method, e.g. for specifying a Sequence that automatically matches all trailing
653     * whitespace after the string.
654     *
655     * @param string the string
656     * @return the rule
657     */
658    @DontExtend
659    protected Rule fromStringLiteral(String string) {
660        checkArgNotNull(string, "string");
661        return fromCharArray(string.toCharArray());
662    }
663
664    /**
665     * Used internally to convert the given char array to a parser rule.
666     * You can override this method, e.g. for specifying a Sequence that automatically matches all trailing
667     * whitespace after the characters.
668     *
669     * @param array the char array
670     * @return the rule
671     */
672    @DontExtend
673    protected Rule fromCharArray(char[] array) {
674        checkArgNotNull(array, "array");
675        return String(array);
676    }
677
678    /**
679     * Converts the given object array to an array of rules.
680     *
681     * @param objects the objects to convert
682     * @return the rules corresponding to the given objects
683     */
684    @DontExtend
685    public Rule[] toRules(Object... objects) {
686        checkArgNotNull(objects, "objects");
687        Rule[] rules = new Rule[objects.length];
688        for (int i = 0; i < objects.length; i++) {
689            rules[i] = toRule(objects[i]);
690        }
691        return rules;
692    }
693
694    /**
695     * Converts the given object to a rule.
696     * This method can be overriden to enable the use of custom objects directly in rule specifications.
697     *
698     * @param obj the object to convert
699     * @return the rule corresponding to the given object
700     */
701    @DontExtend
702    public Rule toRule(Object obj) {
703        if (obj instanceof Rule) return (Rule) obj;
704        if (obj instanceof Character) return fromCharLiteral((Character) obj);
705        if (obj instanceof String) return fromStringLiteral((String) obj);
706        if (obj instanceof char[]) return fromCharArray((char[]) obj);
707        if (obj instanceof Action) {
708            Action action = (Action) obj;
709            return new ActionMatcher(action);
710        }
711        Checks.ensure(!(obj instanceof Boolean), "Rule specification contains an unwrapped Boolean value, " +
712                "if you were trying to specify a parser action wrap the expression with ACTION(...)");
713
714        throw new GrammarException("'" + obj + "' cannot be automatically converted to a parser Rule");
715    }
716
717}
